SRC_DIR = '../input/java-jars'

FILE_EXT = '.jar'        # e.g. could be '.zip'
CONTENT_EXT = '(class)'  # e.g. could be '(html|png)'

STYLE = 'background:white; color:black; white-space: pre;'
SEARCH_ENG = 'https://www.google.com/search?q='
source.766aa590:
import os, re, subprocess from IPython.display import HTML def format_link(m): return f'{m.group(1)}' def add_links(s): return re.sub(f'((\\S+)\\.{CONTENT_EXT})', format_link, s) def make_html(zip_name): s = subprocess.check_output(['unzip', '-l', os.path.join(SRC_DIR, zip_name)]) txt = zip_name.replace(FILE_EXT, '.txt') with open(txt, 'wb') as f: f.write(s) lines = add_links(s.decode('utf-8')) content = f'
{lines}
' return f'

{zip_name}

{content}'
source.1af57bca:
# Java Jars Index

This notebook creates a HTML index of all the Java jar libraries in [this dataset](https://www.kaggle.com/jtrotman/java-jars) including hyperlinks to search for documentation for each [class](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_class_file).

If you want to start programming in Java, for machine learning or anything else, I would recommend setting up a proper IDE, like [Eclipse](https://www.eclipse.org/). Once your code works locally, you can upload the jars to a dataset like this one, then run the java code from a Notebook, as demonstrated [in Java PDFBox Demo: Santa Prime Paths](https://www.kaggle.com/jtrotman/java-pdfbox-demo-santa-prime-paths).


## Tips

Change the constants in the first cell and you can adapt this notebook to create an index listing the contents inside any set of zip files.
